--- title: "\U0001F0CF Permutation Test for Two Proportions" author: "Arvind Venkatadri" date: 10/Nov/2022 subtitle: "Test Proportions" lastmod: "2023-12-31" categories: - Permutation - Monte Carlo Simulation - Random Number Generation - Distributions - Generating Parallel Worlds --- ## Setting up the Packages ::: {.cell hash='one-mean-tutorial_cache/html/setup_eacedbc5f81165599b85477b1cdcf1ae'} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(mosaic) library(ggmosaic) # plotting mosaic plots for Categorical Data ### Dataset from Chihara and Hesterberg's book (Second Edition) library(resampledata) ``` ::: ## Introduction We saw from the diagram created by Allen Downey that *there is only one test*! We will now use this philosophy to develop a technique that allows us to mechanize several *Statistical Models* in that way, with nearly identical code. We will use two packages in R, `mosaic` and the relatively new `infer` package, to develop our intuition for what are called **permutation** based statistical tests. ## Testing for Two or More Proportions Let us try a dataset with Qualitative / Categorical data. This is the General Social Survey GSS dataset, and we have people with different levels of `Education` stating their opinion on the `Death Penalty`. We want to know if these two Categorical variables have a correlation, i.e. can the opinions in favour of the `Death Penalty` be explained by the `Education` level? Since data is Categorical ( both variables ), we need to take `counts` in a table, and then implement a `chi-square test`. In the test, we will permute the `Education` variable to see if we can see how significant its *effect size* is. ::: {.cell hash='one-mean-tutorial_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_1608e6147171c338df9e53d4e02cfabc'} ```{.r .cell-code} data(GSS2002) inspect(GSS2002) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` categorical variables: name class levels n missing 1 Region factor 7 2765 0 2 Gender factor 2 2765 0 3 Race factor 3 2765 0 4 Education factor 5 2760 5 5 Marital factor 5 2765 0 6 Religion factor 13 2746 19 7 Happy factor 3 1369 1396 8 Income factor 24 1875 890 9 PolParty factor 8 2729 36 10 Politics factor 7 1331 1434 11 Marijuana factor 2 851 1914 12 DeathPenalty factor 2 1308 1457 13 OwnGun factor 3 924 1841 14 GunLaw factor 2 916 1849 15 SpendMilitary factor 3 1324 1441 16 SpendEduc factor 3 1343 1422 17 SpendEnv factor 3 1322 1443 18 SpendSci factor 3 1266 1499 19 Pres00 factor 5 1749 1016 20 Postlife factor 2 1211 1554 distribution 1 North Central (24.7%) ... 2 Female (55.6%), Male (44.4%) 3 White (79.1%), Black (14.8%) ... 4 HS (53.8%), Bachelors (16.1%) ... 5 Married (45.9%), Never Married (25.6%) ... 6 Protestant (53.2%), Catholic (24.5%) ... 7 Pretty happy (57.3%) ... 8 40000-49999 (9.1%) ... 9 Ind (19.3%), Not Str Dem (18.9%) ... 10 Moderate (39.2%), Conservative (15.8%) ... 11 Not legal (64%), Legal (36%) 12 Favor (68.7%), Oppose (31.3%) 13 No (65.5%), Yes (33.5%) ... 14 Favor (80.5%), Oppose (19.5%) 15 About right (46.5%) ... 16 Too little (73.9%) ... 17 Too little (60%) ... 18 About right (49.7%) ... 19 Bush (50.6%), Gore (44.7%) ... 20 Yes (80.5%), No (19.5%) quantitative variables: name class min Q1 median Q3 max mean sd n missing 1 ID integer 1 692 1383 2074 2765 1383 798.3311 2765 0 ``` ::: ::: Note how *all* variables are Categorical !! `Education` has five `levels`: ::: {.cell hash='one-mean-tutorial_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_b4a940738113ab0509ef5978c57a4878'} ```{.r .cell-code} GSS2002 %>% count(Education) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} GSS2002 %>% count(DeathPenalty) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: Let us drop NA entries in `Education` and `Death Penalty`. And set up a table for the chi-square test. ::: {.cell hash='one-mean-tutorial_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_84eab12570ee83703ec650f948db1976'} ```{.r .cell-code} gss2002 <- GSS2002 %>% dplyr::select(Education, DeathPenalty) %>% tidyr::drop_na(., c(Education, DeathPenalty)) dim(gss2002) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1307 2 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} gss_summary <- gss2002 %>% mutate( Education = factor( Education, levels = c("Bachelors", "Graduate", "Jr Col", "HS", "Left HS"), labels = c("Bachelors", "Graduate", "Jr Col", "HS", "Left HS") ), DeathPenalty = as.factor(DeathPenalty) ) %>% group_by(Education, DeathPenalty) %>% summarise(count = n()) %>% # This is good for a chisq test # Add two more columns to facilitate mosaic/Marrimekko Plot # mutate(edu_count = sum(count), edu_prop = count / sum(count)) %>% ungroup() gss_summary ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ## Table Plots {#sec-table-plots .tabset .tabset-pills} We can plot a heatmap-like `mosaic chart` for this table. ### Using `ggplot` {.active} ::: {.cell hash='one-mean-tutorial_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_2be30a0ba61d591ae705bce3d18efefb'} ```{.r .cell-code} # https://stackoverflow.com/questions/19233365/how-to-create-a-marimekko-mosaic-plot-in-ggplot2 ggplot(data = gss_summary, aes( x = Education, y = edu_prop)) + geom_bar(aes(width = edu_count, fill = DeathPenalty), stat = "identity", position = "fill", colour = "black") + geom_text(aes(label = scales::percent(edu_prop)), position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5)) + # if labels are desired facet_grid(~ Education, scales = "free_x", space = "free_x") + theme(scale_fill_brewer(palette = "RdYlGn")) + # theme(panel.spacing.x = unit(0, "npc")) + # if no spacing preferred between bars theme_void() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](one-mean-tutorial_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=2100} ::: ::: ### Using `ggmosaic` ::: {.cell hash='one-mean-tutorial_cache/html/mosaic-plot_0f22dcfd514f5ac26503c2070d857be6'} ```{.r .cell-code} #library(ggmosaic) ggplot(data = gss2002) + geom_mosaic(aes(x = product(DeathPenalty, Education), fill = DeathPenalty)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](one-mean-tutorial_files/figure-html/mosaic-plot-1.png){width=2100} ::: ::: ## {.unnumbered} ### Observed Statistic: the X\^2 metric When there are multiple proportions involved, the X\^2 test is what is used. Let us now perform the base `chisq test`: We need a `table` and then the `chisq` test: ::: {.cell hash='one-mean-tutorial_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_d28f2c2eb6d38c6e65b367d4bda315c5'} ```{.r .cell-code} gss_table <- tally(DeathPenalty ~ Education, data = gss2002) gss_table ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Education DeathPenalty Left HS HS Jr Col Bachelors Graduate Favor 117 511 71 135 64 Oppose 72 200 16 71 50 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Get the observed chi-square statistic observedChi2 <- mosaic::chisq(tally(DeathPenalty ~ Education, data = gss2002)) observedChi2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` X.squared 23.45093 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Actual chi-square test stats::chisq.test(tally(DeathPenalty ~ Education, data = gss2002)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Pearson's Chi-squared test data: tally(DeathPenalty ~ Education, data = gss2002) X-squared = 23.451, df = 4, p-value = 0.0001029 ``` ::: ::: What would our Hypotheses be? \$\$ H_0: Education Does Not affect Votes on Death Penalty\\\ H_a: Education affects Votes on Death Penalty\ \$\$ We should now repeat the test with permutations on `Education`: ::: {.cell hash='one-mean-tutorial_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_8ed10024bdb7e911be4641c960faf972'} ```{.r .cell-code} null_chisq <- do(10000) * chisq.test(tally(DeathPenalty ~ shuffle(Education), data = gss2002)) head(null_chisq) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} gf_histogram( ~ X.squared, data = null_chisq) %>% gf_vline(xintercept = observedChi2, color = "red") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](one-mean-tutorial_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=2100} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} prop1(~ X.squared >= observedChi2, data = null_chisq) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` prop_TRUE 0.00029997 ``` ::: ::: The `p-value` is well below our threshold of $0.05%$, so we would conclude that `Education` has a significant effect on `DeathPenalty` opinion! ## Conclusion So, what do you think?
